Patch Set 15:

(3 comments)
Hello Kasun, can you please rebase this onto the tip of the main branch and re-push?
Hi Andrew, I rebased the change. Please take a look now.

Hi Kasun. This is a good start. I've made a few structural comments alongside a few nitpicks. Let me know if anything needs clarification.

I'll hold off on reviewing your later patches until we get consensus on the comments here.

Bit of a nitpick, but it's worth addressing now because it's harder to undo later (this is a public header):

Given this is `libpldm`, prefixing the header name with `pldm_` feels a bit redundant. Excluding `pldm_types.h` none of the other public headers use this prefix (I'm on the fence about whether it's necessary for `pldm_types.h`).

The `#include` directives already look like `#include <libpldm/...>`. In this case we would have `#include <libpldm/pldm_rde.h>`. Essentially I think `#include <libpldm/rde.h>` is an improvement.
Make sense. I changed them to to rde.h and rde.c

We don't have good consistency with header guards, but my preference is that (roughly) we transform the header's path by replacing `/` with `_` and capitalise the letters. So in this case:

```
#ifndef LIBPLDM_PLDM_RDE_H
#define LIBPLDM_PLDM_RDE_H
...
```

And taking into account the file renaming comment above:

```
#ifndef LIBPLDM_RDE_H
#define LIBPLDM_RDE_H
```
Done
Should we be complete for the referenced version of the spec? There are several more defined that aren't listed here.
Good catch! It was just the ones I used. Now I added them all.

I realise that many of the structures in libpldm are defined with `__attribute__((packed))`, but I've put a chunk of effort into giving us a path to avoid it. The internal APIs in `src/msgbuf.h` allow us to not require `__attribute__((packed))`.

What is the feasibility of avoiding its use here and for the other structs in this header?

I see. Yea I wrote this code around the beginning of this year and I was trying to follow the rest of the repo.

I did write everything using __attribute__((packed)). It would require a significant effort for me to change it to using the new API.

I addressed all the comments except the things that depend on the new API. Looks like only some of the decoding functions in platform.c use the new API so far. So would you be Ok to keep this as is for now? or do you prefer to migrate everything to the new API?

So I think there's less of an impact if we keep the RDE encode/decode APIs as they are now (i.e. with the individual parameters, not passing a struct pointer), but use the msgbuf APIs in the implementation, and drop `__attribute__((packed))` from the struct definition. I'd merge that approach, given that it reflects the rest of the encode/decode APIs that already exist. Does that make it more feasible for you? I will be putting up some resistance to merging the current implementation which doesn't use the msgbuf APIs. Let's try to avoid carrying on with the mistakes of the past.

> Looks like only some of the decoding functions in platform.c use the new API so far. 

All of the decode implementations in `src/platform.c` should have been converted over. If I've missed some I'd appreciate if you could point out which 😊 I'd left the encode API implementations alone though, as fixing those was potentially a little harder.

Here's a blog post that motivates the use of the msgbuf APIs:

https://trust-in-soft.com/blog/2020/04/06/gcc-always-assumes-aligned-pointer-accesses/

HN discussion:

https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=37194953
Very interesting post. Thanks for sharing. I changed things to using msgbuf API.
Done
Ack
We can use the types we defined above if we exploit the msgbuf APIs for encoding and decoding. That helps the compiler enforce semantic correctness.
Ack

Can you please include `rde` in the symbol name?

```
int encode_rde_negotiate_redfish_parameters_req(...)
```
Done

With the above suggestions regarding the struct and the internal use of the msgbuf APIs this prototype could potentially take the struct:

```
int encode_rde_negotiate_redfish_parameters_req(
    const struct pldm_rde_negotiate_redfish_parameters_req *req,
    struct pldm_msg *msg);
```

Similarly for the decode API below.
I kept the params similar to the original implementation to minimize the changes I have to do to migrate this to msgbuf API.
Probably only need to add it once 😊
Done

Right, please take a look at the APIs in `src/msgbuf.h`. The commit message outlines some motivations for using it:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/commit/c63f63a2d9d7d25b21b76a1a6098ee1a3176be7e

Here's a small example of implementing a decode function with it:

https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/commit/2d1d1bdf88c03388d467760540543106695ad2e1
Ack
See the comment above regarding the internal msgbuf APIs.
Ack

The `libpldm_` prefix on the test case names came from a time when libpldm was part of openbmc/pldm. It made sense then, but we've since chopped libpldm out into its own repo, and now it's a bit redundant. I'd prefer we don't continue with the tradition now it's passed its used-by date 😊. Maybe we'll eventually rename the other tests to drop the prefix as well.
Renamed the test to rde_test.cpp
Hi Kasun, thanks for the updates. I have a few more queries.
Do you mind if we keep these constants in the implementation (i.e. `src/rde.c`) until we have a strong motivation to expose them in the public headers?
Done
I appreciate that this is an improvement over the previous approach that invoked UB, but what was the reasoning behind avoiding the strategy I suggested on PS5?

> 1. For C++ compilers, string_data property will be missing. So how does this work with a C++ compiler?

The library is a C library and must be compiled with a C compiler (and not a C++ compiler). The library uses features of the C standard that are not part of the subset of C allowed by C++.

`pldm_rde_varstring_data()` is a function provided by the library, therefore it's a function that's compiled with a C compiler, and has access to the `string_data` member.

C++ has access to `pldm_rde_varstring_data()` as a function in the library, and so it can retrieve the pointer by invoking the function.

> 2. Is there an advantage of doing it as above vs simply using a uint8_t *string_data and pointing it to the starting location of the string in a given buffer?

It saves an extra allocation and indirection, and is more cache friendly for short strings.

Thanks for the clarification. Updated the code.

The compiler doesn't allow me to put struct pldm_rde_varstring as a property at the end of struct pldm_rde_negotiate_redfish_parameters_resp. So I removed pldm_rde_negotiate_redfish_parameters_resp struct definition for the moment since it's not really used.

> I removed pldm_rde_negotiate_redfish_parameters_resp struct definition for the moment since it's not really used.

Okay, yes, it's best to avoid defining things that aren't yet used. Otherwise we back ourselves into a corner if we need to change the structure down the track.

> The compiler doesn't allow me to put struct pldm_rde_varstring as a property at the end of struct pldm_rde_negotiate_redfish_parameters_resp. 

Ah, so that my approach prevents embedding is a significant problem. We should probably switch back to your approach of using the pointer. Sorry for the noise there.
Ack. I reverted it back.
Why not test this before we extract the feature support? That way we would not be doing unnecessary work.
Done

Why do we extract to the `feature_support` local rather than passing through `&mc_feature_support->value` to `pldm_msgbuf_extract()` on line 72? The latter approach would make the local variable unnecessary.
As a habit I try to avoid passing pointers of packed array properties. Changed it.

Hi Kasun, apologies for the delay, but I switched employers in between reviews. Hopefully I'll have some more time now. This looks okay, I just have a couple of small comments. Hopefully we can merge it on the next iteration.
Can we move this to the next patch where it's actually required? I don't think anything in this patch needs it.
